conclusion: To determine when particles A and B meet, find the time at which their positions are the same using the area under the velocity-time graph.
The velocity-time graph for particle A is a triangle for the first 2t_0 seconds and a trapezoid for the next 4t_0 seconds.
Calculate the area under the velocity-time graph for particle A for the first 2t_0 seconds: Area_A = 2v_0 t_0.
Calculate the area under the velocity-time graph for particle A for the next 4t_0 seconds: Area_A = 4v_0 t_0.
Total area under the curve for particle A is 6v_0 t_0.
The velocity-time graph for particle B is a straight line that starts at t = 0 and ends at t = 6t_0.
Calculate the area under the velocity-time graph for particle B: Area_B = 3v_0 t_0.
Set the areas equal to each other to find the time at which they meet: 6v_0 t_0 = 3v_0 t_0 + area for the remaining part of A.
The remaining area for A must be 3v_0 t_0, meaning the meeting point is where the areas are equal, at t = 4t_0.
The time at which A and B meet is 4t_0.
